channel.title: Interval Notation
channel.description:
Having a brain fart on this. Can someone show me how to get the domain ex. (-inf, inf) for the following three equations. I know the answer, I just don't know how to get it.
Use interval notation to identify the domain for each of the following functions. a. f(x) = 1/(4x[sup]2[/sup] -21x -18) b. g(x) = sqrt(x[sup]2[/sup] - 5x -14) c. d(x) = ln(2x - 12)

item.title: Interval Notation
item.dc:creator: @jc22493 Jc22493
item.description:
@jc22493 wrote:

Based on Taharok’s post, this is what you should have come up with. I’m not trying to spoonfeed, but if you need to compare your answers with mine, go ahead.

a) 4x^2 - 21x - 18 =|= 0

b) x^2 - 5x -14 ≥ 0

c) ln(2x - 12) > 0 implies 2x - 12 > 1

Then you can just solve for x in each.

Read full topic

item.title: Interval Notation
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

He’s talking about analyzing a function for when it will produce a non-determinate answer. For example, given the function f(x) = 1/x, the domain is (-infinity, 0) U (0, infinity) because you cannot divide by zero. So its domain is all real numbers except 0.

Each of the functions you specified has the ability to produce unreal or non-determinate answers. Square root cannot produce a rational value for negative inputs, so its domain would be all values of x except those which make its input negative. Natural log can receive all positive numbers, so the domain of your third problem will be all values of x that produce a value greater than zero.

Read full topic

item.title: Interval Notation
item.dc:creator: @m1lkman m1lkman
item.description:
@m1lkman wrote:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:2, topic:451604”]You need to establish where it is outside its limit.
a. When you divide on 0.
b. Sqrt of a negative.
c. ln of a negative.

a. 4x² - 21x - 18 = 0
Then the domain is all numbers except x[sub]1[/sub] and x[sub]2[/sub].
b. Make a “line table” or whatever it is called. Where you mark out where is it positive or negative.
c. Based on the previous information you should be able to do this.

I assume you know how to do this, when you know what to do?

(Don’t trust this too much, as I nearly failed in maths)[/quote]

I don’t understand. “When you divide on 0”. What do I divide by 0?

Read full topic

item.title: Interval Notation
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

You need to establish where it is outside its limit.
a. When you divide on 0.
b. Sqrt of a negative.
c. ln of a negative.

a. 4x² - 21x - 18 = 0
Then the domain is all numbers except x[sub]1[/sub] and x[sub]2[/sub].
b. Make a “line table” or whatever it is called. Where you mark out where is it positive or negative.
c. Based on the previous information you should be able to do this.

I assume you know how to do this, when you know what to do?

(Don’t trust this too much, as I nearly failed in maths)

Read full topic
